title: IBS vs. IBD: How to Tell the Difference and Why It Matters

content: If you’ve ever experienced chronic stomach pain, diarrhea, or bloating, you might have wondered whether you have irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Because these two conditions share many overlapping symptoms, they’re often confused, but they are very different in how they develop, how they’re treated, and what they mean for your health. Understanding the difference is key to getting the right care and relief.
What Is IBS?

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common condition that affects how your digestive system functions. It’s considered a disorder of gut-brain interaction, meaning the way your gut and nervous system communicate is altered, which can lead to changes in digestion and sensitivity.

Unlike IBD, IBS does not cause inflammation or permanent damage to the digestive tract. Instead, symptoms are often triggered by things like stress, hormones, certain foods, or disruptions in the gut microbiome.
Common Symptoms of IBS
bullets: Diarrhea, constipation, or a mix of both
Relief of pain after a bowel movement

What Is IBD?
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic condition marked by inflammation and damage in the digestive tract. The two main types are Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis.

IBD can affect different parts of the gut, and the terms used often reflect where inflammation occurs: For example, proctitis (rectum), proctosigmoiditis (rectum and sigmoid colon), distal ulcerative colitis (beyond the sigmoid), or pancolitis (entire colon). Crohn’s disease is often categorized by how it behaves: inflammatory, stricturing (narrowing), or penetrating (causing fistulas).
bullets: Identifying and avoiding food triggers (sometimes with a low-FODMAP diet, ideally guided by a GI-specialized registered dietitian)
Ensuring adequate and appropriate fiber intake
Managing stress through therapy, mindfulness, or exercise
Medications for diarrhea, constipation, or cramping, if needed

content: IBD can also affect more than just the digestive tract. Some people experience joint pain, skin rashes, or eye inflammation. Because inflammation can be severe, some patients may require surgery during their disease course.
Common Symptoms of IBD
Blood tests, stool tests, endoscopy, and imaging often show clear evidence of inflammation or damage.
How IBD Is Managed
The goal of treatment is to induce and maintain remission, followed by regular monitoring even when the disease is controlled. Management typically includes:
bullets: Persistent diarrhea, often with blood or mucus. Fecal incontinence is not uncommon.
Some patients with ulcerative colitis may present with constipation when the disease is localized to the rectum.
Prescription medications tailored to disease severity, such as aminosalicylates, corticosteroids, immunomodulators, or biologics
Nutrition support and dietary strategies, including adequate fiber and energy intake
Surgery in severe cases to remove damaged sections of the intestine
Mental health support as part of comprehensive care

sections.heading: Can IBS Turn Into IBD?
content: A common myth is that IBS can “turn into” IBD over time – but this isn’t true. IBS does not progress into Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis.

However, some people with IBD who are in remission may continue to experience symptoms like bloating or abdominal pain. This may be due to overlapping GI conditions such as IBS or small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO). A thorough evaluation by your care team is important to ensure an accurate diagnosis and the right treatment approach.
When to See a Doctor
Because symptoms can overlap, it’s important not to self-diagnose. See a health care provider if you experience:
These could be signs of IBD or another serious condition. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent complications and improve quality of life.
The Bottom Line

IBS and IBD may sound similar and feel similar, but they are very different conditions. IBS is a functional disorder with no inflammation or gut damage, and it’s usually managed through diet, stress management, and medical management. IBD, on the other hand, is an inflammatory autoimmune disease that causes tissue damage and often requires medication or surgery.

content: If you’re dealing with ongoing digestive symptoms, don’t try to figure it out alone. Talking with a gastroenterologist can help you get the right diagnosis, treatment, and support, and give you the best chance to feel like yourself again.
